body.p: A quality control engineer at a potato chip company tests the bag-filling machine by weighing bags of potato chips. Not every bag contains exactly the same weight. But if more than 15% of bags are overfilled, then they stop production to fix the machine.
They define overfilled to be more than 1 ounce above the weight on the package. The engineer weighs 100 bags and finds that 21 of them are overfilled.
He plans to test the hypotheses: H0: p = 0.15 versus Ha: p > 0.15 (where p is the true proportion of overfilled bags). What is the test statistic?

response.feedback: Correct. The sample proportion is about 1.68 standard errors above the p = 0.15 using the formula z = (p-hat − p)/√[(p(1 − p)/n].
Incorrect. It looks like you switched the order of the sample proportion and the population proportion in the numerator.
Incorrect. It looks like you calculated p(p) rather than p(1 − p) in the denominator of the formula z = (p-hat − p)/√[(p(1 - p)/n].

Incorrect. It looks like you switched the value of the sample proportion and the population proportion in the formula. You should use 0.15 for p and 0.21 for p-hat in the formula z = (p-hat − p)/√[(p(1 − p)/n].

body.p: According to a Pew Research Center, in May 2011, 35% of all American adults had a smartphone (one which the user can use to read email and surf the Internet). A communications professor at a university believes this percentage is higher among community college students.

She selects 300 community college students at random and finds that 120 of them have a smartphone. In testing the hypotheses H0, P = 0.35, versus Ha, p > 0.35, she calculates the test statistic as Z = 1.82.
Use the normal table to identify the appropriate p-value for this Z score.
Click here to access the normal table.
Given these results, which of the following is an appropriate conclusion?

input.choice: There is enough evidence to show that more than 35% of community college students own a smartphone (p-value = 0.034).
There is enough evidence to show that more than 35% of community college students own a smartphone (p-value = 0.068).
There is not enough evidence to show that more than 35% of community college students own a smartphone (p-value = 0.966).
There is not enough evidence to show that more than 35% of community college students own a smartphone (p-value = 0.034).

response.feedback: Correct. The area to the right of Z = 1.82 on the standard normal curve is about 0.034. This is smaller than α = 0.10 so we reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative.
Incorrect. You doubled the correct P-value. We double the P-value when the test is two-sided. The test is two-sided when the alternative hypothesis uses the inequality ≠. The conclusion is correct.
Incorrect. You used the area to the left of Z = 1.82 as your P-value. Because the alternative hypothesis is p > 0.35, we use the area to the right of the test statistic as the P-value.
Incorrect. Although your P-value is correct, your conclusion is not correct. The P-value is smaller than α = 0.10 so we reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative.

body.p: A manufacturer of t-shirts marks a shirt as “irregular” when it has defects such as crooked seams, stains, rips, or holes. A small number of irregular t-shirts are expected as part of the manufacturing process, but if more than 8% of the t-shirts manufactured at a plant are classified as irregular, the manager has to do an investigation to try to find the source of the increased mistakes in the manufacturing process.
In order to test whether his plant is making a higher than expected number of irregular t-shirts, the manager of a plant randomly selects 100 t-shirts and finds that 12 are irregular.
He plans to test the hypotheses: H0, P = 0.08, versus Ha, p > 0.08 (where p is the true proportion of irregular t-shirts). What is the test statistic?

response.feedback: Correct. The sample proportion is about 1.47 standard errors above the p = 0.08 using the formula z = (p̂ − p)/√[(p(1 − p)/n].
Incorrect. It looks like you switched the order of the sample proportion and the population proportion in the numerator.
Incorrect. It looks like you calculated p(p) rather than p(1 − p) in the denominator of the formula z = (p̂ − p)/√[(p(1 − p)/n].

Incorrect. It looks like you switched the value of the sample proportion and the population proportion in the formula. You should use 0.08 for p and 0.12 for p̂ in the formula z = (p̂ − p)/√[(p(1 − p)/n].

body.p: According to a 2015 survey by mobile loyalty company SessionM, 47% of smartphone users preferred online shopping to in-store shopping. A professor at a local community college believes that the percentage of smartphone users who prefer online shopping may be higher among community college students.

She randomly selects 150 community college students with smartphones and she finds that 84 of the students surveyed prefer online shopping. In testing the hypotheses: H0: p = 0.47 versus Ha: p > 0.47, she calculates the test statistic as Z = 2.21. The alpha level for this problem is 0.05. Use the Normal Table to identify the appropriate p-value for this Z score.

There is enough evidence to show that more than 47% of community college with smartphones prefer online shopping (p-value = 0.0272).
There is not enough evidence to show that more than 47% of community college with smartphones prefer online shopping (p-value = 0.9864).
There is not enough evidence to show that more than 47% of community college with smartphones prefer online shopping (p-value = 0.0136).
